column6: description of relevance

A fictionalized depiction of King Yeongjo’s son, Crown Prince Sado’s life and death. He died in 1762 after being confined in a rice chest. Crown Prince Sado’s life and death is described in the autobiography, Hanjungnok한중록Memoirs of Lady Hyegyeong.

column3: 왕의 남자 The King and the Clown
column6: Set during the Joseon Dynasty.

Set in 18th Century Korea, this film is based on the Chʻunhyangdyŏn, a classic pansori folktale. The판소리 (p'ansori) is a Korean musical genre that includes a singer and a drummer. Also see Sŏp'yŏnje.
column11: Korean; English; Chinese; Japanese (Asian Library); English (Koerner Library);

column6: Set in 1933, Korea was under Japanese colonial rule and resistance movements and members were exiled abroad such as to Shanghai. In Shanghai, the Korean National Revolutionary Party was formed and led by Kim Won-bong. In addition, Kim Goo was the leader of the Korean independence movement who was an important political figure during immediate post-1945 period.

Set amidst Korea under Japanese colonization in the 1930s. The film uses a contrast of Korean and Japanese names and the hierarchy of language. The character, Uncle Kouzuki, is also a wealthy Korean man during colonial rule because of his role as a collaborator.

Depicts Korean collaborators, a term used for Korean citizens who worked with/for the Japanese government in order to obtain status, money, and power. Korean independence resistance movements/fighters were located in Korea and abroad such as in Shanghai.
Depicts the political tensions on the Korean peninsula in 1948 as civil and external influences rise. Based on the novels by조정래Cho Chŏng-nae

column3: 자유 만세Chayu manse Hurrah! For freedom
column6: Film created immediately following Korea’s independence. Depicts a Korean resistance fighter.

Following the Korean War, the lands and livelihood of the citizens were devastated. In this setting, this film depicts the intergenerational conflict following the Korean War regarding a stance of pro or anti-communism.

column3: 태극기 휘날리며Tʻaegŭkki hwinallimyŏ Tae Guk Gi: The Brotherhood of War
column6: Set during the Korean War, starting from the outbreak of the conflict in 1950. Addresses the separation of family, defection and accusations of such between the south and north, and the devastation of the war.

column3: 군번 없는 용사Kunbŏn ŏmnŭn yongsa A hero without a serial number
column6: Depiction of the outbreak of the Korean War, fighting, and family separation
column11: Korean; Japanese; Chinese; English, French; Spanish; Russian.

column6: Depiction of early outbreak and fighting of the Korean War outbreak. Specifically addresses the initial outbreak of war and North Korean entry into South Korea. Also addresses Operation Chromite and the cooperation with UN forces.
column11: Korean; English; Japanes; Chinese; Russian; Spanish; French.

column3: 남부군Nambugun North Korean Partisan in South Korea
column6: Based on a novel and true story by이태 Lee Tae. Depicts a perspective of the Korean War from a North Korean partisan.
Primarily addresses the ending events of the Korean War including the final battles and shaping of an armistice/ceasefire

column3: 자유 부인Chayu Puin Madame Freedom Freedom
column6: Set following the Korean War, this film explores the post-war experience through the protagonist, Oh Seon-yeong. It explores the post-war economic conditions and class, especially through the presence of ‘Western’ imports such as makeup, fashion, and music. In addition, the social conditions and sentiments on the roles of women in this time are explored through the morally challenging relationships depicted.
column11: Korean; English; Japanese; Chinese; Russian; Spanish; French; Arabic

column3:
지옥화 Chiokhwa The flower
in hell
column6: Set in post-war Seoul, the protagonist, Sonya, works at an American military base as a prostitute. The film comments on the reality of life after the Korean War and the presence of American military bases in South Korea. The film notably has a military base setting, focus on Korean prostitutes, explore the value placed on American goods (e.g., beer, music), and the black market established for these products. These notes highlight the intersections of war, economic struggle, and the interactions between Korean citizens and American soldiers.

This film follows a male protagonist who works as a music teacher
at a textile factory. One of the girls at the textile factory is hired to work
for his family as a housemaid. Following the Korean war, poor rural families sent
women to newly established factories in the city in order to earn income. The
hiring of rural women as housemaids (see
The Handmaiden) and ‘factory girls’ were not new however; the latter arose
amidst industrialization in the 1920s. Notably, the director also explores the
experience of ‘Western’ imports such as fashion and norms. In summary, this
film explores class dynamics and ‘factory girls’ in post-war Korea.

The film’s
message and depiction of the grim life in post-war Korea, led to the film’s ban
by the government upon release. The film focuses on the protagonist, an office
clerk, who desperately struggles to make ends meet for his family. The sister
is a prostitute for American soldiers stationed on military bases in South
Korea., a consequence of an unfinished war. The aftermath of the Korean War is
seen through the brother, an unemployed and injured Korean War veteran. And
most significantly through the characterization of the mother, who expresses
trauma from experiencing the Korean War. Based on a novella of the same name by
Yi Pŏm-sŏn.

Based on a short story by Yi Ch'ŏng-jun. Set in the early 1960s
but includes flashbacks to the Japanese colonial period. The판소리 (p'ansori) is a
Korean musical genre that includes a singer and a drummer. Also see Chunhyang. DIsappearing way of life

column3: 육체 의 고백 Yukch'e ŭi kobaek The body confession
column6:
Explores the
intergenerational role of women and economic struggles amid the post-war. Includes
footage from the April 19 movement that led President Rhee Syngman’s
resignation from power.
column11: Korean; Japanese; Chinese; English; French; Spanish; Russian

column6:
Based on a true story; Based on a novel. In 1968, North Korean soldiers failed to
assassinate President Park Chung-hee. In response, Unit 684 was formed to
assassinate North Korean leader, Kim Il-sung.

Park Chung-hee led a coup d'état in 1962 and entered presidency.
The film depicts events leading up his death. Park was assassinated by the head
of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency (KCIA), Kim Jae-gyu, on October 26,
1979.

column3: 그때 그사람들 The President's Last Bang
column6:
About the assassination of President Park
Chung-hee. See: The Man Standing Next

column3:
아름다운 청년 전태일 Arŭmdaun
chʻŏngnyŏn Chŏn Tʻae-il  A Single Spark
column6: Jeon Tae-il was a 22 year old labour activist who committed suicide in 1970 by igniting himself on fire, in protest of the working conditions in garment factories. Specifically, he worked in Seoul at the Pyeonghwa Market where he witnessed the terrible working conditions of young girls. Under President Park Chung-hee’s industrialization efforts, there was a growing intensive working conditions. Jeon was and continues to be a significant figure for labour activists in South Korea

South Korean soldiers participated in the Vietnam War and were the
largest force to fight alongside the United States.

column3: 영자 의 전성 시대 Yŏng-ja ŭi chŏnsŏng sidae Yeong-ja's heydays
column6:
Male protagonist leaves and returns as a South Korean soldier of
the Vietnam War. The female protagonist, Yeong-ja, presents an interconnection
of struggles. She experiences many jobs such as being a housemaid for a wealthy
family, a low paid factory worker in a garment factory, and a prostitute.
column11: Korean; English; Japanese; Chinese; Russian; Spanish; French; Arabic

column3:
국제시장 Kukche Sijang Ode to
my father
column6:
Covers an intergenerational story
from the Korean War, post-war life, Korean diaspora in Germany, and the Vietnam
War.
column7: Korean War; Post-War; Korean Diaspora; Vietnam War

column3: 님 은 먼 곳 에 Nim ŭn mŏn kot e
column6:
“Love story set
amid the Vietnam War.” [From record summary]

Addresses the experience of soldiers
following participation in the Vietnam War.

“The story of a family
torn apart by conflicting loyalties during and after the Korean War.” [From record summary]
column11: Korean; English; Japanese; Chinese; Russian; Spanish; French; Arabic.

column3: 택시 운전사 T'aeksi unjŏnsa A taxi driver
column6:
Based on a true story; The Gwangju Uprising in 1980, a pro-democracy
uprising that was violently shut down by the military government of President
Chun Doo-hwan. The film depicts the story of Jürgen Hinzpeter, a German TV
reporter who captured footage of Gwangju through the help of Kim Sa-bok, a taxi
driver. Mr. Kim’s identity was unknown until after the release of this film.

Depicts reunification with separated
families. The film includes direct footage from the KBS Live Broadcast, 이산가족을 찾습니다 (Finding Dispersed Families), that
aired in 1983 to help reunify relatives. The broadcast’s archive has been
included in UNESCO’s Memory of the World Register since 2015. See http://family.kbsarchive.com/ (KOR), http://english.kbsarchive.com/ (ENG).
column11: Korean; English; Japanese; Chinese; Russian; Spanish; French; Arabic.

column3: 고래 사냥 Korae sanyang Whale hunting
column6: Depiction of 1980s South Korea.

column3:
꼬방 동네 사람들 Kkobang
tongne saramdŭl
People in the slum
column6: Depiction of poverty and slums in South Korea.

Based on a true story; a memoir by Kim Geun-tae. The film depicts
the interrogation and torture committed by the police under Chun Doo-hwan’s
presidency. At the time, democracy activists, (suspected) communist sympathizers,
and dissenters were arrested. Also see: 1987: When the Day Comes.

Based on a true story; Park Jong-chul was a 21 year old university
student who was tortured for information and died in custody of the police. His
death was significant to the June Democracy Movement of 1987.

column3:
칠수 와 만수 Ch’il-su
wa Man-su
column6:
The film’s setting depicts elements of 1980s cultural and politicalclimate. Notably, the popularity of ‘Western’ music, movies (e.g., Rocky), and food is portrayed.
In addition, both Chilsu and Mansu experience consequences withstanding from the Korean War. Altogether, this film presents a portrayal of a disillusioned working class, the long-lasting effects of the Korean War, and the cultural landscape of the 1980s.

column3: 살인의 추억 Sarin ŭi ch'uŏk  Memories of Murder
column6:
Based on the 화성 연쇄 살인 사건 (Hwaseong serial
murders) that took place from 1986-1991. The case was unsolved until 2019, when
the perpetrator confessed while in prison for a different crime. The film
depicts the lack of crime investigation technology in Korea at the time, and an
important background is also the democracy efforts/conflicts and the
authoritarian regime at the time.

In 1991, the South and North Korean table tennis teams competed as a unified, Korea at the World Table Tennis Championships. This was in result of talks from an inter-Korean summit where tensions were high on the peninsula as
in 1987, North Korean agents bombed Korean Air flight 858 mid-flight.

Based on a true story; about the Somali civil
war in 1991 and the South Korean embassy's escape from the area of conflict, in
cooperation with the North Korean embassy.

column3:
그 섬 에 가고 싶다 Kŭ
sŏm e kago sipta To the Starry Island
column6:
Depicts the longing effects of the Korean War and political
affiliation amid the 20th century, particularly being a communist sympathizer. Also see film, Chilsu wa Mansu.

The Sampoong Department Store Collapse of 1995 was an event that marked critical failure of leadership and required reflection on the cost of rapid development and negligence. [Depicts the event but it is not the central
plot]

Touches on an idea of Korean reunification. Reflects changing sentiments in approaching North Korea and the 햇볕정책
(Sunshine Policy) introduced by President Kim Dae-jung in 1998.

The protagonist’s story is shown through flashbacks of major
periods and events in late 20th C Korean history. Notably, the 1980 Gwangju
Uprising, democratization movements, torture under the military government,
rapid industrialization/economic growth, and the IMF Crisis.

column3:
국가 부도 의 날 Kukka pudo ŭi nal
Default
column6:
Depicts events surrounding the 1997 IMF
Crisis in South Korea.

Based on the novel, DMZ by박상연 Park Sang-yeon (1997). Touches on an idea of Korean reunification. Reflects changing sentiments in approaching North Korea and the 햇볕정책 (Sunshine Policy) introduced by President Kim Dae-jung in 1998.
The central ensemble of the film depicts different remnants of 20th century Korea such as the son who is a former political activist (see 1980s) and failed university graduate.

Follows the life of a ‘Bacchus Lady’, a term for elderly women who
work as a sex worker under the guise of selling Bacchus energy drinks. Explores
historical and contemporary social issues such as American-Korean relations, elderly
poverty, aftermath of the IMF crisis, and Korean-Filipino (Kopino) children.

column3: 아이 캔 스피크 I Can Speak

column11: For titles with multiple access points, subtitles may vary between them. Please check the Notes of each item.
